thread.title: RBA governor Glenn Stevens hits out at ‘short-termism’, calls for focus on growth
thread.title_full: RBA governor Glenn Stevens hits out at ‘short-termism’, calls for focus on growth

author: Michael Roddan
title: RBA governor Glenn Stevens hits out at ‘short-termism’, calls for focus on growth
text:
RESERVE Bank governor Glenn Stevens says the focus of reform debate in Australia should be on economic growth, rather than debates on the timeline for returning the Budget to surplus.
Mr Stevens has also hit out at the short-term focus of fiscal policy.
Speaking at the National Reform Summit today, Mr Stevens said desirable economic growth could not be delivered by only interest rate cuts or short-term fiscal initiatives.
It needed more sustainable sources, he said.
“The kind of growth we want won't be delivered just by central bank adjustments to interest rates or short-term fiscal initiatives that bring forward demand from next year, only to have to give it back then,” Mr Stevens said.
The RBA has trimmed interest rates twice this year in a bid to stimulate the sluggish economy, putting the official cash rate at its lowest point on record — 2 per cent.
Mr Stevens also added his thoughts to recent musings that the new normal for Australian economic growth was below its historical average of 3.25 to 3.5 per cent.
“Growth rates have mostly started with a ‘2’ for a while now — despite the lowest interest rates in our lifetimes,” he said.
“Growth is important. And for a while now, there has not been quite enough growth.”
“This may be simply a feature of the post-financial crisis world — the need for balance sheet repair. It may be about changing demographics.
“It may be that potential growth is a bit lower than we used to think, though I don't think we can know whether that is so at present.”
The summit, in Sydney, is being hosted by The Australian and the Australian Financial Review .
Mr Stevens said fiscal policy debate in Australia was usually framed between discussions of “when do we get back to surplus” or debates about “fairness”.
But Mr Stevens said the debate should focus on “how do we grow the pie?”.
“That isn't because distribution doesn't matter. It's because distributional issues surely get easier with growth but much, much harder in its absence.”
Originally published as Glenn Stevens hits out at ‘short-termism’
